title: Children International
content:
{{Infobox Organization 
| name = Children International
| abbreviation = CI
| image = Children International Logo.jpg
| size  = 200px
| motto = "Real help.  Real hope."
| formation= 1936<ref>http://www.children.org/about.asp?sid=DEE83412-7E14-454C-8DF9-08F0C5C13C11</ref>
| type = NGO
| status = Foundation
| purpose = Eradicating child poverty
| headquarters = [[Kansas City, Missouri|Kansas City]], MO<ref>http://www2.children.org/en/us/Pages/home.aspx?sid=B62C54B2-0F5C-40AA-B154-F489C2AE1581</ref>
| leader_title = CEO
| leader_name = Susana Eshleman<ref name="char">https://www.children.org/Articles/Article/11547</ref>
| website = [http://www.children.org/ www.children.org]
}}

'''Children International''' is a [[nonprofit]] humanitarian [[organization]] that supports children and prepares youth to escape [[poverty traps]]. It addresses children’s critical needs through early intervention and regular interaction in community centers.<ref name="children.org">https://www.children.org/About-Us</ref> The goal is to help children overcome the effects of poverty, support their education, and prepare youth to contribute to society.<ref>http://www.ecuadortimes.net/2011/04/16/children-international-fundation-and-its-desire-to-train-good-citizens/</ref>

The organization provides health benefits, such as annual medical exams and care during illness. If a child needs more advanced health intervention, the organization assists in providing referrals to specialists.<ref>http://expreso.ec/expreso/plantillas/nota_print.aspx?idArt=4320506&tipo=2; http://www.eluniverso.com/noticias/2013/06/10/nota/1008121/ciudad</ref> Beyond these critical needs, Children International provides nutritional support, dental care, counseling for children and families, school supplies and fees, clothing, and items for the home.<ref>http://www.bbb.org/charity-reviews/national/child-sponsorship/children-international-in-kansas-city-mo-1815/conclusions</ref> It also engages youth through leadership development opportunities, scholarships, and financial and job-skills training.<ref>https://www.children.org/Youth-Programs</ref> An example of youth programming is "Into Employment," where participating youth receive training in welding, electrical, refrigeration and industrial mechanics.<ref>http://www.ramanmedianetwork.com/hsbc-helps-to-provide-job-training-to-poor-youth/</ref> Youth may also take courses on sales techniques, customer service, accounting, critical thinking and leadership. <ref> http://expreso.ec/expreso/plantillas/nota.aspx?idart=7364369&idcat=38269&tipo=2 </ref> The international hotel chain [[InterContinental]] is one business working with the charity to provide job skills training for youth in Mexico. <ref>http://www.milenio.com/region/Paraisos_del_Colli_y_Villa_de_Guadalupe-capacitacion_para_empleo-Zapopan_capacita_a_jovenes_0_277172776.html</ref>

Children International runs other notable programs including a school feeding program in Zambia.<ref>http://www.postzambia.com/post-read_article.php?articleId=9924&post_reply=1&comments_threshold=0&comments_reply_threadId=15785&comments_offset=0&thread_sort_mode=commentDate_asc&comments_per_page=20&comments_grandParentId=0&comments_parentId=15785&thread_style=commentStyle_plain,</ref> The organization also distributes wheelchairs to needy communities via a gift-in-kind program.<ref>http://daily-mail.co.zm/blog/2013/07/11/wheelchair-gift-dream-come-true-for-boy-14/</ref> With support from Houghton Mifflin Harcourt,<ref>http://www.hmhco.com/~/media/sites/home/AboutHMH/Files/82_MS100031_CSR_Annual_Report_HR.pdf</ref> Children International offers a global community literacy program. The charity has been recognized for giving out books in the Philippines,<ref>http://www.businessweekmindanao.com/2014/03/20/palawan-rep-hagedorn-spearheads-donation-of-17000-books-computers/</ref> Kenya,<ref>http://www.the-star.co.ke/news/article-162490/20000-books-gift-kiambu-schools</ref> and Malawi.<ref>http://www.nyasatimes.com/2014/02/18/children-international-us-donates-books-to-malawi-schools/</ref> The organization also hosts reading tents in Uganda.<ref>http://www.newvision.co.ug/mobile/Detail.aspx?NewsID=18405&CatID=6</ref><ref>http://nabotu.or.ug/a-poor-reading-culture-sabotages-the-citys-programmes/</ref>

Children International engages in humanitarian aid after disasters. Recently, they provided assistance in the [[Philippines]] after [[Typhoon Haiyan]], distributing personal care supplies,<ref>http://www.orlandomagazine.com/Orlando-Magazine/December-2013/Clean-Sweep/</ref> and clothing, food, water and other relief.<ref>http://www.kshb.com/news/local-news/kansas-city-based-children-international-seeks-financial-help-with-relief-efforts-in-the-philippines</ref> Children International also pledged to assist the recovery effort with rebuilding and other aid.<ref>http://watch.ktwu.org/video/2365145009/</ref>

==Approach==

According to the Children International website, the organization aims to "reduce the burden of poverty on impoverished children, invest in their potential and provide them with opportunities to grow up healthy, educated and prepared to succeed and contribute to society."<ref name="children.org"/>  The organization delivers these results via its community centers, which offer programs, computers, libraries and other educational tools.<ref name="sites.mediaplanet.com">http://sites.mediaplanet.com/latin-america/childrens-empowerment-overcoming-life-in-the-red-zone</ref> Educational support of this kind is frequently absent or difficult to acquire in impoverished areas, leading to secondary illiteracy and educational lags.<ref>http://www.webpages.uidaho.edu/~mbolin/ogunsola.htm</ref>  Community centers serve as a distribution network for aid, although the focus is on using each center as "a unique support system" that offers skill and leadership training, college preparation and confidence building.<ref name="sites.mediaplanet.com"/> Children International has indicated that its interests lie in cross-sector work with private industry, local and national governments, individuals and other non-governmental organizations.<ref>http://sites.mediaplanet.com/latin-america/panel-of-expert-questions-investing-in-latin-america-and-the-caribbean</ref> 
Children International uses a child sponsorship model to fund these activities, with nearly all of its funding coming from private donations.<ref>http://www.leawoodlifestyle.com/2012/04/27/one-child-at-a-time-charity-alters-lives/</ref> Funds are transferred to each agency, which oversee the organization’s community centers, according to an approved budget.

==History==

Known in its earlier years as "Holy Land Christian Mission," Children International was founded in 1936.<ref>http://www.csmonitor.com/1981/0806/080657.html/(page)/8</ref>  The organization distributed food baskets to widows and poor families, provided early childhood education<ref>http://pdf.usaid.gov/pdf_docs/PDAAQ597.pdf</ref> and operated a small medical clinic as well as a children’s home for orphans. This clinic was expanded following a polio outbreak in 1952 and became larger and more sophisticated over the years.<ref>http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10254095</ref> Eventually known as the Mt. David Crippled Children’s Hospital, the clinic provided critical orthopedic medical services<ref>http://pdf.usaid.gov/pdf_docs/PNABY746.pdf</ref> until its closure.

In the 1980s, the organization began expanding its scope by launching sponsorship agencies in Guatemala, Colombia, Honduras and the Dominican Republic.<ref>http://www.csmonitor.com/1981/0806/080657.html/(page)/5</ref> It would later change its name to Children International.<ref>http://www.sos.mo.gov/kbimaging/8503313.pdf</ref>

Children International is currently a secular organization which supports equal participation for all children regardless of religion.<ref>http://community.liftone.org/service/displayDiscussionThreads.kickAction?as=121091&w=255061&d=657025</ref> The organization operates in 10 countries, including Colombia, the Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Guatemala, Honduras, India, Mexico, the Philippines, the United States and Zambia.<ref>https://www.children.org/Where-We-Work</ref>

== Mission ==

Children International's mission is to bring real and lasting change to children living in poverty. In partnership with contributors, we reduce their daily struggles, invest in their potential, and provide them with the opportunity to grow up healthy, educated and prepared to succeed and contribute to society.<ref name="children.org"/>

The organization has begun work in [[WASH]] --  water, sanitation and hygiene. They have completed a number of projects with [[Caesars Entertainment Corporation]] <ref>http://vegasinc.com/business/notes/2014/apr/06/notes-philanthropy-april-6-12/</ref> and Clean the World, a group that recycles and distributes toiletries from the hospitality industry. <ref>http://www.mynews13.com/content/news/cfnews13/news/article.html/content/news/articles/cfn/2014/6/16/hero_shawn_seipler.html</ref> Dan Phelan, a philanthropist from [[Alpharetta, Georgia]], has also worked with the organization in bringing clean water to people in the Dominican Republic. <ref>http://alpharetta.patch.com/groups/goodnews/p/alpharetta-lawyer-embarks-on-clean-water-project</ref> In partnership with the Planet Water Foundation, Children International has brought water-filtration systems to communities in India, the Philippines and the Dominican Republic. <ref>http://www.justmeans.com/blogs/aqua-water-tower-changing-lives-in-india-philippines-and-the-dominican-republic</ref>

== Celebrity supporters ==

Singer and longtime CI supporter [[Debbie Gibson]] was featured as a contestant on the 2012 season of The Celebrity Apprentice on NBC. From the show, she raised $50,000 for CI and her winnings went towards the construction of a community center to serve 5,000 poor children in New Delhi, India. The community center will include a medical and dental clinic, pharmacy, library, computer lab and playground. The center will allow impoverished children to receive much-needed health care and educational support they would not have otherwise.<ref>http://www.multivu.com/mnr/52275-singer-debbie-gibson-win-trump-celebrity-apprentice-children-international</ref> In 2014, Gibson again demonstrated her support for the organization by donating proceeds from her appearance on the television show “Celebrity Home Raiders” to them.<ref>http://www.broadwayworld.com/bwwtv/article/New-Series-CELEBRITY-HOME-RAIDERS-to-Premiere-on-Lifetime-36-20140129</ref>

In addition to [[Debbie Gibson]], Children International has a dedicated base of celebrity supporters who have graciously agreed to lend their names and faces in support of bringing real and lasting change to families around the world.

Joel Lambert, the ex-[[Navy SEAL]] star of the [[Discovery Channel]] show [[Lone Target]], has discussed his support of the organization and sponsorship of a Filipino boy through the Children International program.<ref>http://lifestyle.inquirer.net/156051/the-hunt-is-on</ref>

[[James Valenti]], an American operatic tenor, has been vocal about his support of Children International and has visited its operations in the Dominican Republic.<ref>http://www.myssnews.com/mysslife/entertainment/23390-james-valenti-catching-up-with-popular-charismatic-tenor.html</ref><ref>http://www.chicagocrusader.com/(S(dzpvyd0l55clwn1bjofsp0hv))/chicago/News-Detail.aspx?CityID=1&newsID=4556&typeID=4</ref>
[[Marco Antonio Regil]], a Mexican television personality and game show host, cites Children International as one of his charities<ref>http://uptownlatino.net/Magazine/ourcommunity/marco-antonio-regil-por-la-puerta-grandeM</ref> and has filmed commercials in support of the organization.<ref>http://marcoantonioregil.com/marco/organizaciones/children-international/</ref>

In August 2014, [[Paola Espinosa]], a Mexican diving and synchronized swimming champion, announced her collaboration with Children International and its sports program. <ref>http://www.notimerica.com/deportes/noticia-clavadista-paola-espinosa-ya-mira-olimpiadas-rio-2016-20140811172026.html</ref>

The list of other celebrities who support the organization includes [[Edie Falco]], [[Drew Carey]], [[Christian Finnegan]], [[Heather Graham]], [[Helio Castroneves]], [[Miranda Kerr]], [[Hannah Teter]],<ref>http://www.bankrate.com/lite/celebrity-money/richest-american-olympians-sochi-5.aspx</ref><ref>http://guyism.com/sports/countdown-sochi-2014-hannah-teter.html</ref> and [[Neil Patrick Harris]] and [[David Burtka]].<ref>http://aumag.org/wordpress/2014/04/05/david-burtka/</ref><ref>https://www.children.org/Celebrity-Supporters</ref>

[[Image:TonalaCommunityCenterF.jpg|thumb|alt=Community Center.|Santa Paula Community Center in Tonalá, Jalisco, México.]]

==Partnerships and alliances==
Children International has worked with a number of organizations and agencies.

===USAID===
With the support of [[USAID]], Children International launched A Ganar, a work training program in Guatemala in early 2014.<ref>http://www.prensalibre.com/deportes/mas_deporte_nacional/Programa-A_ganar-deporte-apoyo_0_1105089531.html</ref> Previously, the charity piloted a program with USAID/Colombia called Hope for Colombia’s Children that trained youth in conflict resolution.[32] The two organizations have also distributed books together in the Philippines.[33]

===Peace Corps===
Children International has worked with the U.S. [[Peace Corps]] in a number of countries. The organization has trained Peace Corps volunteers in Guatemala,<ref>http://files.peacecorps.gov/multimedia/pdf/media/PCTimes2012_partnership_ed.pdf</ref>  and has worked on several water-related projects in the Philippines, including a sanitation project<ref>http://appropriateprojects.com/book/export/html/1349</ref> and installation of water pumps.<ref>http://appropriateprojects.com/book/export/html/940</ref> In 2014, the organizations co-authored a comprehensive youth leadership training manual titled “Leadership Training through Project Design and Management.” <ref>http://3blmedia.com/News/CSR/Peace-Corps-Philippines-and-Children-International-Partner-Create-and-Implement-Youth</ref>

===United Nations===
Children International assisted the [[United Nations]] on its global campaign [[United_Nations# "A Million Voices: The World We Want" report from the global consultations|The World We Want]]. The UN recognized the organization’s efforts to include poor children’s opinions in the effort. <ref> http://blog.myworld2015.org/2014/08/06/children-international-gives-children-and-youth-a-say-at-the-un/</ref>

===Aflatoun===
Children International began its partnership with [[Aflatoun]] in 2010, when it implemented its programs in three countries: Ecuador, India and the Philippines.<ref>https://www.alipesnews.com/App.aspx#id=3191229000000004&languageId=4000</ref> Children International has since expanded Aflatoun to its sponsorship areas, including Colombia,<ref>http://www.aflatoun.org/docs/children-and-change/children-and-change-2012.pdf?sfvrsn=2</ref> and Honduras.<ref>http://aflatoun.www002.estate.nl/docs/stakeholder-meetings/multiple-stakeholder-meeting-in-bogot%C3%A1.pdf?sfvrsn=2</ref><ref>http://aflatoun.www002.estate.nl/docs/default-document-library/2012_ci_honduras_childrenactivitiesreport.pdf?sfvrsn=2</ref> In November 2013, Children International launched the first Aflatoun program in the United States at its Little Rock, Arkansas, location.<ref>http://hosted.verticalresponse.com/423549/8a2c82d455/1473648105/5ef6bc221f/</ref>

In 2012, sponsored child Carla Vasquez from Guayaquil, Ecuador, was awarded the Youth Champion Award in Geneva, Switzerland, by Child and Youth Finance.<ref>http://www.aflatoun.org/blogs/blog/2012/05/11/award-to-carla-%289%29-from-ecuador-for-leading-her-aflatoun-club</ref> In 2013, Children International had two children, one from Ecuador and one from India, qualify as finalists with their Aflatoun projects at the [http://www.childfinanceinternational.org 2013 Child and Youth Finance Summit] in Istanbul, Turkey.<ref>http://www.aflatoun.org/blogs/blog/2013/05/17/aflatoun-kids-win-award-at-cyfi-2013-summit</ref>

===TOMS Shoes===
As part of their One-for-One shoe program, [[TOMS Shoes]] worked with Children International to distribute shoes in a Philippine community hard hit by [[Typhoon Haiyan]].<ref>http://www.philstar.com/ystyle/2014/03/07/1297823/giving-shoe</ref> TOMS recognized Children International as a Giving Partner in July 2014. <ref> https://www.toms.com/stories/giving/introducing-toms-giving-partner-children-international</ref>

===PAHO===
During A Promise Renewed for the Americas, a 2013 gathering of organizations including [[USAID]] and the Pan American Health Organization ([[PAHO]]/[[World Health Organization]]), 18-year-old sponsored youth Nelson Hernandez Jimenez signed the Declaration of Panama on behalf of Children International. The document recognizes a continuing commitment to address issues of child, maternal, and reproductive health in the region.<ref>http://www.apromiserenewedamericas.org/apr/</ref>

===Operation Change===
Children International was featured on [[Oprah Winfrey]]'s [[Oprah_Winfrey_Network_(U.S._TV_channel)|OWN]] original program “Operation Change” in 2014. The show focused on the organization’s [[Developmental_psychology#Early childhood|early childhood development]] efforts in [[India]] <ref>http://www.operationchange.com/project/children-international</ref> and sports program in [[Colombia]].<ref> http://www.operationchange.com/project/empower-with-sports</ref>

===Aura's House===
[[Aura's House]]<ref>http://aurashouse.com/2015/04/one-last-call-to-action-auras-house-will-be-closing-after-current-projects-fund/</ref> worked with Children International on Small Scale, Doable Projects.

===UNICEF===
Sponsored youth in the Philippines, trained by Children International, have assisted [[UNICEF]] in disaster relief.<ref>http://www.csrwire.com/press_releases/29846-Teen-Volunteers-from-Children-International-and-UNICEF-Provide-Emotional-Help-to-Typhoon-Affected-Children-in-the-Philippines</ref> Children International has also implemented a child protection policy based on the tenets of UNICEF’s Core Commitments for Children in Emergencies.<ref>http://www.unicef.org/publications/index_21835.html</ref><ref>https://www.children.org/Articles/Article/11014</ref>

===Eli Lilly===
The [[Eli Lilly and Company]]'s Lilly MDR-TB Partnership worked with Children International to create a public awareness campaign in India in 2009 that continued for several years.<ref>http://transworldnews.com/NewsStory.aspx?ID=110609</ref><ref>http://www.reuters.com/article/2010/10/05/idUS135439+05-Oct-2010+PRN20101005</ref> Sponsored youth, trained as Youth Peer Educators (YPE), supported [[tuberculosis]] patients during their treatment and worked as change agents to decrease stigma about the disease and increase overall community awareness of the illness.<ref>https://www.lillyindia.co.in/pdf/Lilly%20MDR%20TB%20Brochure.pdf</ref>

===Pan-American Games===
Children International was named sole charity partner  for the 2011 [[Pan-American Games]].<ref>http://www.hispanicallyspeakingnews.com/latino-daily-news/details/pan-american-games-teams-up-with-children-international-a-u.s.-charity/10951/</ref> Subsequently, it released the video "Soy Panamericano".<ref>http://www.tumtiki.com/videos/1988430/dailymotion_children-international-soy-panamericano-video</ref>

===Americorps===
Children International's United States' program, located in Little Rock, Arkansas, partners with [[Americorps]].<ref>https://my.americorps.gov/mp/listing/viewListing.do?id=38414</ref> 
Celebrity Apprentice 
Singer-songwriter Debbie Gibson played for Children International on NBC’s 12th season of The Celebrity Apprentice, winning $50,000 for the charity.<ref>http://www.ibtimes.com/celebrity-apprentice-winner-debbie-gibson-donate-prize-money-children-international-424250</ref>

===DigiBayanihan===
DigiBayanihan is a movement that seeks to champion digital literacy among Filipinos. The campaign was initiated by a multistakeholder partnership including organizations such as Intel Philippines and Children International – Philippines that have come together to empower the underserved. <ref>http://www.gadgetsmagazine.com.ph/events/digibayanihan-targets-to-tap-5-million-filipinos-by-end-of-2015.html</ref>

== Withdrawal from Chile ==
In May 2014, Children International started withdrawing its operations from Chile. Letters were sent to sponsors of Children in Chile informing them that their sponsorship of the child had come to an end and assigning them a new child to sponsor in another country.
Children International claims that the reason for their pull-out is that the situation in Chile has improved to the point where they are not needed as the economy is improving and the government is taking care of the healthcare and education needs of the impoverished. Children International had three service centers in Chile, serving over 17000 children, all of which are being closed.

==Reception==
*UALR Children International is part of a collaboration that received a $1.2 million grant from the National Science Foundation. The grant will launch a new program aimed at improving Arkansas’ early education opportunities in [[science, technology, engineering and mathematics]]. <ref>http://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2015/sep/14/1-19m-grant-aids-ualr-s-stem-majors-201/</ref>
* Dilnasheen Alamgir, a former sponsored child in Kolkata, India, runs a small business recycling waste materials and turning them into handicrafts. Her entrepreneurship was recognized at the 2014 Children and Youth Finance International meeting held at the [[UN]] and [[UNICEF]] headquarters in New York.<ref> http://www.mangalorean.com/news.php?newstype=local&newsid=484094</ref>
* In 2014, Kelli Suen, a former sponsored child who served as the youth council president at Children International’s Little Rock, Arkansas, program, was awarded a [[Disney’s Friends for Change]] grant.<ref>http://www.katv.com/story/25173182/teen-leads-project-to-provide-homeless-survival-kits</ref> She used the funds to assemble survival kits for the homeless in her community.<ref>http://www.therepublic.com/w/AR--Homeless-Survival-Kits</ref>
* Paula Rogers received the 2014 [[Lewis Hine]] Award from the [[National Child Labor Committee]] in New York. Rogers is Children International’s education manager in Little Rock, Arkansas, and she oversees programs for students in kindergarten through 12th grade.<ref>http://www.arkansasbusiness.com/article/97139/scott-copas-moves-into-new-role-as-bob-shell-assumes-chairmans-seat-at-baldwin-shell-movers-shakers</ref>
* Children International received the National Gawad Kalasag Award in the Philippines and was the Hall of Fame Awardee for having won as Best Civil Society Organization on Humanitarian Assistance for three (3) consecutive years (2010-2012).<ref>http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/01/31/children-intl-award-idUSnPnMM50792+160+PRN20130131</ref>
* Ingrams Magazine identified the organization as the top area non-profit organization for [[Kansas City]], the location of Children International’s world headquarters. <ref>”TTop Area Non-Profit Organizations.” Ingram’s Greater Kansas City Book of Leads & Lists, 2015, p. 71.</ref>
* In 2012, [[Consumers Digest]] named CI one of their "top-rated charities."<ref>https://www.consumersdigest.com/images/uploads/article/Charities_2012_chart.pdf</ref>
* [[Charity Navigator]] gives Children International 3/4 stars.<ref name="char" />
* The [[Better Business Bureau]] has given CI accredited status, meaning that it "meets all 20 Standards for Charity Accountability and is a Seal Holder."<ref>http://www.bbb.org/charity-reviews/national/child-sponsorship/children-international-in-kansas-city-mo-1815</ref>
* Children International is part of the Combined Federal Campaign, which promotes charitable giving among government workers in the United States.  Its number is 12078.<ref>http://www.opm.gov/cfc/</ref>
* The National Disaster Coordinating Council in the Philippines awards Children International top honors in disaster relief.<ref>http://www2.children.org/en/us/News/InTheNews/2011/Pages/Philippine-Government-Recognizes-US-Based-Charity-3-29-11.aspx?</ref>
* [[Charity Watch]] rated Children International a "B+" grade.<ref>Charity Rating Guide and Watchdog Report, Volume Number 59, December 2011</ref>
* Users on [[Great Nonprofits]] rated Children International with an average 4- out of 5-star rating.<ref>http://greatnonprofits.org/reviews/children-international</ref>
* [[Forbes]] magazine recognized Children International, a U.S.-based humanitarian organization, as a top U.S. charity in its "Top 100 Largest U.S. Charities" list for 2012. The Forbes list includes ratios regarding a nonprofit's level of fundraising efficiency and charitable commitment<ref name="Forbes">http://www.forbes.com/companies/children-international/</ref> and the press release. <ref name="biz">http://www.bizjournals.com/prnewswire/press_releases/2012/11/19/MM14943</ref>

==References==
{{reflist|colwidth=30em}}
http://www.children.org/YouthReportCard.asp
http://www.children.org/celebrity

==External links==
* {{Official website|http://www.children.org/}}
* [http://www.facebook.com/children.international Official Facebook page]
* [https://www.children.org/MyAccount/Account/LogOn Children International My Social Center community page]

content: == July 2010 == [[Image:Information.png|25px]] Welcome to Wikipedia. title: Name blending
content:
'''Name blending''' or '''meshing''' is the practice of combining two existing names to form a new name.<ref name="Barnett">Emma Barnett, "[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/women/womens-life/9664227/Couples-fuse-surnames-in-new-trend-I-now-pronounce-you-Mr-and-Mrs-Puffin.html Couples fuse surnames in new trend: ‘I now pronounce you Mr and Mrs Puffin’]", ''The Telegraph'' (November 9, 2012).</ref> An example is the combination of the [[surnames]] Dresser and McLoughlin to form the new surname of game designed [[Clay Dreslough]]. It is most commonly performed upon [[marriage]]. According to Western tradition, the wife normally adopts the husband's surname upon marriage. Name blending is an alternative practice that attempts to assign equal cultural value to each partner's surname. In November 2012 it was reported that 800 couples in the United Kingdom had opted to blend their surnames thus far that year, primarily among "younger couples in their twenties or early thirties", with this being a leading reason for the issuance of [[Deed Polls]] to change names.<ref name="Barnett"/>

Since the late 1990s, it has also become common for [[celebrity]] couples to be given blended names in the media, usually made by combining elements of the [[given name]] of the people involved.<ref name="Clements">Erin Clements, "[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/04/18/kimye-celebrity-nicknames_n_1435267.html Kimye, Brangelina, Bennifer: The Evolution Of Celebrity Couple Nicknames]", ''[[Huffington Post]]'' (April 18, 2012).</ref>

Finally, name blending can also occur unintentionally when a double name created in one generation becomes combined and condensed in later generations.<ref>Adrian Room, ''An Alphabetical Guide to the Language of Name Studies'' (1996), p. 45.</ref>

==Motivation==


Many reasons are given for name-blending.

* Couples may choose to adopt a blended name to enter into marriage "with a completely new start without any history being tied to their surname". Name blending confers the same surname upon both spouses. This allows the family to conform to the expectation that the family (and any children) will all share the same name, and avoid confusion that can arise when spouses retain differing surnames.<ref>[[Eviatar Zerubavel]], ''Ancestors and Relatives: Genealogy, Identity, and Community'' (2012), p. 84: "Claiming our multiple roots and thereby acknowledging our genealogical complexity also imply claiming our multiple identities and thereby recognizing our existential complexity, as exemplified when we decide to give children surnames that would provide a bilateral account of their origins. Such practices may include compounding the parents' surnames (as when Ruderman and Wilgoren are compounded into Rudoren, Villar and Raigosa into Villaraigosa, and Dell and Osborne into Delborne), although they usually involve combining them through hyphenation. In both cases, however, the very notion of privileging one line of descent over the others is rejected, and the memory of more than just one ancestral past is formally preserved".</ref><ref name="Barnett"/>
* Name blending avoids the patriarchal practice of having the wife take the husband's name. In doing so, it is considered by many to be an extension of the [[feminist movement]]. <ref>Katie Roiphe, [http://www.slate.com/id/2097231/ The Maiden Name Debate: What's changed since the 1970s?], ''[[Slate.com]]'' (March 16, 2004).</ref> 
* Name blending avoids hyphenation and the complications associated with having a [[double-barreled surname]] or other form of combined name that may be too long for use in some circumstances (for example, many computer databases limit last names to 16 characters).<ref name="Tuhus-Dubrow">Rebecca Tuhus-Dubrow, "[http://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/24/fashion/babies-surnames-to-hyphenate-or-not.html Children of the Hyphens, the Next Generation]", ''[[The New York Times]]'' (November 23, 2011).</ref>
* Name blending often creates a unique surname. In a world with over 1 billion internet users, having a unique last name can make it easier for people to find you using search engines. It also increases the chance that your name will be available as a username in e-mail systems and online communities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kk.org/ct2/2008/07/googleunique-names.php|title=GoogleUnique Names|author=Kevin Kelly|publisher=ct2}}</ref>
* Name blending also provides an alternative for [[same-sex marriage]]s, where there are not longstanding traditions regarding the taking of one participants surname by the other.<ref name="Tuhus-Dubrow"/>

In the case of celebrity couples, where the names are chosen by the media (or arise from the public) rather than reflecting a choice by the couple, it has been suggested that the assignment of a nickname makes fans feel closer to the couple.<ref name="Clements"/> The popularity of celebrity [[supercouple]] [[Ben Affleck]] and [[Jennifer Lopez]] from 2002 to 2004 resulted in their being known by the [[portmanteau]] "Bennifer" (for Ben and Jennifer) to the media, as well as to fans using the name combination.<ref name="NEws.bbc.co.uk">{{cite news | title=Designer hopes for love in games | publisher=BBC NEWS | accessdate=2007-06-15| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/6434471.stm | date=2007-03-09 | first=Darren | last=Waters}}</ref><ref name="www.comcast.net">{{cite web|title=Top Celebrity Supercouples of All Time|publisher=[[Comcast]]/[[Comcast Interactive Media]]|year=2009|accessdate=2009-12-05|url=http://www.comcast.net/slideshow/entertainment-supercouples/20/}}</ref> The term ''Bennifer'' itself became popular, and started the trend of other celebrity couples being referred to by the combination of each other's first names, as with [[Brad Pitt]] and [[Angelina Jolie]] ("Brangelina"),<ref name=www.comcast.net/><ref name="www.theage.com.au">{{cite news| title=The Brangelina fever|publisher=''[[The Age]]''|date=2006-02-06|accessdate=2007-04-14|url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2006/02/06/1139074140202.html | location=Melbourne}}</ref> and [[Kanye West]] and [[Kim Kardashian]] ("Kimye").<ref name="Clements"/> Robert Thompson, director of the Centre for the Study of Popular Television, said "as silly as it sounds, this new tendency to make up single names for two people, like 'Bennifer' (Ben Affleck and Jennifer Lopez) and 'TomKat' (Tom Cruise and Katie Holmes), is an insightful idea'. 'Brangelina' has more cultural equity than their two star parts".<ref name="www.theage.com.au"/>

==Notable people with blended surnames==

*[[Clay Dreslough]], Game Designer (from Dresser and McLoughlin)
*Michael Flaherman, Venture Capitalist (from Flaherty and Silverman)
*[[Antonio Villaraigosa]], former Mayor of Los Angeles (from Villar and Raigosa)
*[[Alexa PenaVega]], actress (from birth surname Vega and spouse's surname Pena)<ref>{{cite web|author=Fahy, Collette|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2534033/Spy-Kids-actress-Alexa-Vega-ties-knot-Nickelodeon-star-Carlos-Pena-18-months-divorce-Sean-Covel.html |title=Spy Kids actress Alexa Vega ties the knot with Nickelodeon star Carlos Pena 18 months after her divorce from Sean Covel. After that, they changed their surname to PenaVega. On July 28, 2015, it was announced that the two had amicably separated.|newspaper=[[Daily Mail]]|date=January 5, 2014}}</ref>

==References==

'''Mundo Maya International Airport''' ({{lang-es|Aeropuerto Internacional Mundo Maya}}) {{Airport codes|FRS|MGMM}}, formerly '''Flores International Airport''' as indicated by its [[International Air Transport Association airport code|3-letter code]], is an international airport located in the suburb of [[Santa Elena, El Petén|Santa Elena]], in the city of [[Flores, El Petén|Flores]], Guatemala. It serves national and international air traffic for the areas of Flores, Santa Elena, and San Benito, as well as all the Mayan sites like [[Tikal]] or [[Yaxhá]] and destinations like Guatemala City and Belize.

Mundo Maya Airport, as the other airports in Guatemala, is going through some expansions, to provide a better service to passengers and airlines, so it will be able to accept a greater number flights and larger aircraft.
In 2012, the ICAO airport identifier for Mundo Maya International Airport changed from MGTK to MGMM.<ref name="JeppView">Jeppesen. ''JeppView''. Version 3.7.5.0.</ref>

==Airlines==
{{Airport-dest-list
|[[Avianca Guatemala]] | [[La Aurora International Airport|Guatemala City]]
|[[Transportes Aéreos Guatemaltecos]] | [[La Aurora International Airport|Guatemala City]]
|[[Tropic Air]] | [[Philip S. W. Goldson International Airport|Belize City]]
}}

==Accidents and incidents==
*On 30 September 1977, [[douglas C-47|Douglas C47A]] TG-AKA of [[Aviateca]] was damaged beyond economic repair in a landing accident. One of the three crew members was killed.<ref name=ASN300977>{{cite web|url=http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=19770930-2 |title=TG-AKA Accident description |publisher=Aviation Safety Network |accessdate=5 August 2010}}</ref>
*On 26 July 1978, [[Douglas DC-3]] TG-AFA of Aviateca overran the runway following a birdstrike on take-off and was reported to have been damaged beyond economic repair.<ref name=ASN260778>{{cite web|url=http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=19780726-0 |title=TG-AFA Accident description |publisher=Aviation Safety Network |accessdate=1 August 2010}}</ref> The aircraft was later repaired and returned to service.<ref name=TGAFA>{{cite web|url=http://www.airlinefan.com/airline-photos/1797133/Aviateca/Douglas/DC-3/TG-AFA/ |title=Photo: Aviateca, Douglas DC-3 TG-AFA |publisher=Airline Fan |accessdate=2 August 2010}}<!--Note that photo is dated 1980--></ref>
*On 7 May 1979, Douglas DC-3 TG-SAB of [[Transportes Aéreos Profesionales|TAPSA]] was substantially damaged in a landing accident when it departed the runway and collided with a car. The aircraft was subsequently repaired and returned to service.<ref name=ASN070579>{{cite web|url=http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=19790507-0 |title=TG-SAB Accident description |publisher=Aviation Safety Network |accessdate=29 July 2010}}</ref>
*On 18 January 1986, a [[Sud Aviation Caravelle|Sud Aviation SE-210 Caravelle III]] from [[Aerovias]], crashed into a hill on its final approach, about 8 km from the airport. All 93 passengers and crew on board were killed, making it the worst air disaster in Guatemalan history.<ref>{{cite web |title=Guatemala crash toll now put at 93 |url=http://www.nytimes.com/1986/01/20/world/guatemala-crash-toll-now-put-at-93.html |publisher=''The New York Times'' |date=20 January 1986|archiveurl= |archivedate=  |accessdate=1 October 2013}}</ref> See also: [[1986 Aerovias Guatemala air crash]].

The '''Gouda–Den Haag railway''' is a heavily used [[railway line]] in the [[Netherlands]], running from [[Gouda, South Holland|Gouda]] to Den Haag ([[The Hague]]), passing through [[Zoetermeer]]. The line was opened in 1870.

==Stations==
The main interchange stations on the Gouda–Den Haag railway are:

*[[Gouda railway station|Gouda]]: to [[Rotterdam]] and [[Leiden]]
*[[Zoetermeer]]: to [[RandstadRail]] light rail network
*[[Den Haag Centraal railway station|Den Haag Centraal]]: to Rotterdam, [[Leiden]] and Amsterdam

{{DEFAULTSORT:Gouda-Den Haag railway}}
[[Category:Railway lines in the Netherlands]]

title: Langeria
content:
{{Speciesbox
|image = File:Langeria magnifica 02.jpg
|image_width = 150px
|image_caption = ''L. magnifica''
|genus = Langeria
|species = magnifica
|authority = [[Jack A. Wolfe|Wolfe]] & [[Wesley Wehr|Wehr]]
}}

'''''Langeria''''' is an [[extinct]] genus of [[flowering plant]] in the family [[Hamamelidaceae]], commonly known as the [[witch-hazel]] family,<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.co.il/books?id=Jf1bbevG5TMC&pg=PA243|title=Life in Stone: A Natural History of British Columbia's Fossils|first=Rolf |last=Ludvigsen|year=2011|publisher=UBC Press|isbn=0774841516|page=243}}</ref> containing the solitary species '''''Langeria magnifica'''''. The species is known from [[fossil]] leaves found in the early [[Eocene]] deposits of northern [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington State]], United States<ref name="WandW87">{{cite journal |last1=Wolfe |first1=J.A. |last2= Wehr |first2=W.C. |year=1987 |title=Middle Eocene dicotyledonous plants from Republic, northeastern Washington |journal= United States Geological Survey Bulletin |volume=1597 |pages=1–25}}</ref> and similar aged formations in [[British Columbia]], Canada.<ref name="Dillhoff2005">{{cite journal |last1=Dillhoff |first1=R.M. |last2=Leopold |first2=E.B. |last3=Manchester |first3=S.R. |year=2005 |title=The McAbee flora of British Columbia and its relations to the Early-Middle Eocene Okanagan Highlands flora of the Pacific Northwest |journal=Canadian Journal of Earth Sciences |volume=42 |issue=2 |pages=151–166 |doi=10.1139/e04-084}}</ref>

==History and classification==
''Langeria magnifica'' has been identified from a series of locations ranging from the [[Klondike Mountain Formation]] near [[Republic, Washington]] north. At least three locations in British Columbia have ''Langeria'' fossils, including the Quilchena locality near [[Merritt, British Columbia|Merritt]], the [[McAbee Fossil Beds]] near [[Kamloops, British Columbia|Kamloops]], and the Joseph Creek site near [[Chu Chua, British Columbia|Chu Chua]]. Generally speaking, the age for the locations is [[Early Eocene]], with the sites that have current [[Uranium-lead dating|Uranium-lead]] or [[Argon–argon dating|Argon–argon]] radiometric dates being of [[Ypresian]] age, while the undated sites and sites with less current dating being possibly slightly younger and [[Lutetian]] in age.<ref name="Greenwood2005">{{cite journal |last1=Greenwood |first1=D.R. |last2=Archibald |first2=S.B. |last3=Mathewes |first3=R.W |last4=Moss |first4=P.T. |year=2005 |title=Fossil biotas from the Okanagan Highlands, southern British Columbia and northeastern Washington State: climates and ecosystems across an Eocene landscape |journal=Canadian Journal of Earth Sciences |volume=42 |issue=2 |pages=167–185 |doi=10.1139/E04-100}}</ref>

''Langeria magnifica'' was described from a series of [[type specimens]], the actual [[holotype]] specimen being UW 39713, in the [[paleobotany|paleobotanical]] collections of [[Burke Museum]], University of Washington, and its [[Compression fossil|counterpart]] being UCMP 9273, currently preserved in the [[University of California Museum of Paleontology]]. An additional eight leaves from both the Burke Museum and UC Museum of Paleontology were designated [[paratype]]s specimens. Working from those specimens, collected in the [[Republic, Washington]] area in the early 1980s, the fossils were studied by [[Jack A. Wolfe]] of the [[University of California]] and [[Wesley C. Wehr]] of the Burke Museum.<ref name="WandW87"/> They published their 1987 [[Type (biology)|type description]] for the genus and species in a [[United States Geological Survey]] [[monograph]] on the North Eastern Washington dicot fossils. The genus name ''Langeria'' is a [[matronym]] honoring the American [[Philosophy of mind|philosopher of mind]], [[Susanne K. Langer]], who influenced the analysis and organization of scientific data.<ref name="WandW87"/> The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] ''magnifica'' would imply "magnificently large". Wolfe and Wehr note that the extinct species ''[["Fortunearia" weedi]]'' is distinctly similar to ''Langeria magnifica'' and might turn out to be [[Congener (biology)|congeneric]].<ref name="WandW87"/>

==Description==
The simple leaves of ''Langeria magnifica'' are generally [[Pinnation|pinnate]] in venation with an overall ovate to elliptical shape and an apex that is notably pointed. The [[Petiole (botany)|petiole]] can reach lengths of up to {{convert|6|cm|in|abbr=on}} The margin of the leaf has evenly spaced, distinct hook-shaped teeth with rounded [[Sinus (botany)|sinuses]] separating them.<ref name="WandW87"/> The teeth are entered by a secondary vein or by a veinlet from the loop of a secondary vein. The primary vein has between ten and twelve secondary veins diverging from it at low angles toward the apex and getting higher in angle towards the base. The simple or forking tertiary veins diverge from the {{convert|0.3|-|0.5|cm|in|abbr=on}} apart, and the quaternery ones form a coarse reticulated pattern surrounding the [[areole]]s.<ref name="WandW87"/>

==References==

[[Category:Prehistoric plants]]
[[Category:Eocene plants]]
[[Category:Monotypic Saxifragales genera]]

title: The Adventures of Kit Carson
content:
{{Infobox television | show_name = The Adventures of Kit Carson | image = File:The Adventures of Kit Carson.jpg|180px | caption = Title card | genre = [[Western (genre)|Western]] | creator = | writer = | director = [[John English (director)|John English]] (and others) | starring = [[Bill Williams (actor)|Bill Williams]]
[[Don Diamond]]
[[Tris Coffin]] | theme_music_composer = | opentheme = | composer = | country = United States | language = English | num_seasons = 4 | num_episodes = 103 | list_episodes = | executive_producer = | producer = Richard Irving | camera = [[Single-camera setup|Single-camera]] | runtime = 25 minutes | company = [[MCA Television]]
[[Revue Studios]] | distributor = [[Revue Productions]]
[[Studios USA Television]] | channel = [[Broadcast syndication|Syndication]] | picture_format = [[Black-and-white]] | audio_format = [[Monaural]] | first_aired = {{Start date|1951|08|11}} | last_aired = {{End date|1955|11|22}} | status = Ended }} '''''The Adventures of Kit Carson''''' is an American [[Western (genre)|Western]] series that aired in [[Television syndication|syndication]] from August 1951 to November 1955, originally sponsored by [[Coca-Cola]]. It stars [[Bill Williams (actor)|Bill Williams]] in the title role as frontier scout [[Kit Carson|Christopher "Kit" Carson]]. [[Don Diamond]] co-starred as "El Toro", Carson's Mexican companion. ==Synopsis== ''The Adventures of Kit Carson'' was intended for children, and presents a fictionalized version of Carson and his life. In the series, Kit Carson roamed the West with his companion El Toro, seeking to help those in need. Kit rode a horse named Apache.Terrace, Vincent (2009). ''Encyclopedia of Television Shows, 1925 through 2007'' (Volume 1). Jefferson, North Carolina: McFarland & Company, Inc. ISBN 978-0-7864-3305-6. ==Cast and characters== *[[Bill Williams (actor)|Bill Williams]] as Kit Carson *[[Don Diamond]] as El Toro *John L. Cason as Carl Rigby *[[Peter Mamakos]] as El Broho *Richard Avonde as Don Felipe *[[Tris Coffin|Tristram Coffin]] as Colonel Culver *[[Francis McDonald]] as George ===Guest stars=== *[[Rico Alaniz]], four episodes, including the role of [[Joaquin Murrieta]] in "California Outlaws" (August 11, 1951), series premiere{{cite web|url=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0505989/?ref_=nm_flmg_act_75|title="California Outlaws", ''The Adventures of Kit Carson'', August 11, 1951|publisher=[[Internet Movie Data Base]]|accessdate=May 15, 2014}} *[[Brett King]] as Brad Randall in "The Teton Tornado" (1951) *[[Nan Leslie]], five episodes (1953-1954) *[[Ewing Mitchell]], three episodes (1951-1952) *[[Mike Ragan]], four episodes, "The Dry Creek Case", "Trails Westward", "The Wrong Man", and "Trail to Bordertown" (all 1954) * [[William Tannen (actor)|William Tannen]], seven episodes (1951-1953) *[[Carol Thurston]], six episodes (1952-1953) ==Production notes== The series was filmed by [[Revue Studios]] at the ranch of [[Ray Corrigan]], later purchased by [[Bob Hope]], near [[Simi Valley, California]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{imdb title|0043169}} * {{tv.com show|the-adventures-of-kit-carson|The Adventures of Kit Carson}} *[https://archive.org/details/KitCarsonDesperateSheriff1951 Public domain episode on Internet Archive] {{DEFAULTSORT:Adventures Of Kit Carson, The}} [[Category:1951 American television series debuts]] [[Category:1955 American television series endings]] [[Category:1950s American television series]] [[Category:Black-and-white television programs]] [[Category:English-language television programming]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of people]] [[Category:First-run syndicated television programs in the United States]] [[Category:Television series by Universal Television]] [[Category:Western (genre) television series]] [[Category:Television series set in the 19th century]]

title: Honde Valley
content:
{{Infobox mountain
| name = Honde Valley
| photo = Honde Valley (3140413431).jpg
| photo_caption = Honde Valley in 1996
| elevation_m = 780
| elevation_ref = at [[Hauna]]
| prominence = 
| map = Zimbabwe
| map_caption = Location of Honde Valley in Zimbabwe
| label_position = left
| listing = 
| location = {{flag|Zimbabwe}}
| range = 
| lat_d = 18 | lat_m = 29 | lat_s = 48.40 | lat_NS = S
| long_d = 32 | long_m = 51 | long_s = 11.52 | long_EW = E
| region_code = ZW
| coordinates_ref = 
| topo = 
| type = 
| age = 
| first_ascent = 
| easiest_route = 
}}

The '''Honde Valley''' extends from the eastern border of [[Zimbabwe]] into [[Mozambique]]. The valley is formed as part of the [[Eastern Highlands]] mountain range. The Valley is about 130 km from [[Mutare]], or 110 km from [[Nyanga, Zimbabwe|Nyanga]]. [[Mount Inyangani]] and the [[Nyanga National Park]] forms the western boundary of the valley.

==Access==
Approaching from Mutare, the turn-off is about 50 km along the road towards [[Nyanga, Zimbabwe|Nyanga]]. The road into the valley is tarred and twists and turns steeply as it drops 800 meters in about 20 km. Off the tarred road, there are good dust roads which service most parts of the Valley.ojo
kjiylhl

==Geography==

===Climate===
The climate of Honde Valley falls within the Savannah sub. From late October to around the end of April, the weather is hot and humid. Temperatures may rise up to 28 ˚C and this is the period where most of the rainfall is received. From May to the beginning of July, the temperatures are very low and they may hover around minimums of 2 ˚C while August is very windy. From September to October, it is very hot and the maximum temperatures may average 30 ˚C.
Most of the rainfall experienced is of the convectional type. At time orographic rainfalls at various times of the year, in addition to the normal convectional rainfall. This portion of the country, therefore, receives the highest rainfall in the country.

===Topography===
The average altitude of Honde Valley is around 900m above sea-level as compared to its immediate surroundings which rise above 1800m. This abrupt drop in topography creates the spectacular Mtarazi and adjacent Muchururu Falls, local tourist attractions.

===Flora===
The 500 square kilometres of the Honde Valley in Zimbabwe are extensively cultivated, often with gravity fed irrigation channels. Extensive use is made of the many smaller tributaries feeding into the [[Pungwe River]] in this portion of the Honde Valley.<ref name="flora">[http://www.zimbabweflora.co.zw/speciesdata/utilities/utility-display-records-by-person.php?person_id=5 Flora of Zimbabwe] Flora of Zimbabwe: Records made by Bob Drummond</ref>

===Fauna===
Honde Valley is one of the premier birding destinations in Zimbabwe, offers a wide range of species difficult to find in most other parts of the region, other than in neighbouring Mozambique. This fertile valley lies 850m above sea level and is one of the major tea producing areas of Zimbabwe.<ref name="birding">[http://www.sabirding.co.za/birdspot/120204.asp Honde Valley Birding Spots] Southern African Birding</ref>

'''Specials:''' Anchieta's tchagra, moustached grass-warbler, red-winged warbler, black-winged bishop, red-faced crimsonwing, lesser seedcracker, singing cisticola, twinspot indigobird which parasitizes the red-throated twinspot, scarce swift, pallid honeyguide, green-backed woodpecker, stripe-cheeked greenbul, yellow-streaked greenbul, silvery-cheeked hornbill, white-eared barbet, pale batis, black-throated wattle-eye, variable sunbird, bronzy sunbird, olive sunbird, yellow-bellied waxbill, grey waxbill, blue-spotted wood-dove, black-fronted bush-shrike.

'''Habitats:''' Lowland and riverine forest, marsh, miombo woodland, tea estate, maize lands.

'''Birding:''' There are four main birding areas in the valley, the area around Aberfoyle Club; Gleneagles Nature Reserve above the Club, eastern Highland Tea Estate; and Katiyo Tea Estate some 25 km from Aberfoyle.

===Water resources===
The water supply for the Honde Valley comprises small piped systems and motorised pumps serving small towns, growth points, commercial plantations, service centres and some villages, as well as direct abstractions from the rivers by riparian village communities not connected to developed installations.

There are a total of about seven small to medium-sized metered piped water systems at [[Hauna]], Sachisuko, Honde Army, [[Zindi]], Samanga, Mpotedzi and Sahumani. In addition there are other smaller un-metered water supply schemes that serve a number of villages and schools. The known smaller un-metered water supply schemes are Honde “Povo” Pipe Scheme, Chingaira Piped Scheme, St Columbus Secondary School, Sagambe Primary and Secondary School, Marige Water Project, Mahobo Piped Scheme and Mupenga Gravity Water Scheme.

==Economy==
Since the area is low-lying and hot it is an abundant [[tea]] and [[coffee]] growing area. The well known Katiyo, Aberfoyle, Rumbizi and Chiwira Tea Estates are among those situated in the valley. However, it is also home to many small scale and susbsistence farmers.<ref name="passport">[http://www.fao.org/uploads/media/Green%20Harvest_%20The%20Outgrower%20Tea%20Leaf%20Collection%20System%20in%20the%20Honde%20Valley_%20Zimbabwe.pdf Green Harvest: The Outgrower Tea Leaf Collection System in the Honde Valley, Zimbabwe] J P Mtisi</ref> There are several non-motorized irrigation schemes in Honde valley.<ref>[http://www2.warwick.ac.uk/fac/sci/eng/research/dtu/pubs/wp/wp32/wp32.pdf Working Paper No. 32. Assessment of the Potential for Non-motorised Irrigation of Small Farms from Streams in Manicaland, Zimbabwe]. Development Technology Unit. Department of Engineering, Warwick University, Coventry (January 1991)</ref>

One of the main townships inside the valley is [[Hauna]]. [[Hauna]] Growth Point now has a community Hospital.

===Tea estates===
* Eastern Highlands Tea Estate,
* Katiyo Tea Estate,
* Aberfoyle Plantations
* Rumbizi and Chiwira tea estates

=== Business centers ===
* '''[[Hauna]] Growth point''' - Hauna Growth point is located in the Honde Valley communal land about 95 km north of Mutare.It is the Growth Point Centre for Mutasa District in Manicaland.There is an aerodrome where small aeroplanes can land and take off.There is also a Police camp called Ruda Police Station which controls all police activities in that part of Mutasa District. There is also Hauna Hospital.It can be reached by a tarred road from Mutare and cellphone coverage is also available on the net-one,telecel and econet networks.
* '''Zindi Business centre'''

==Education==
Honde Valley has a number of schools and tertiary institutions.

===Secondary schools===
{{Div col|colwidth=15em}}
*[[Sagambe Secondary School]]
*[[Chavhanga Secondary School]]
*[[Chisuko Secondary School]]
*[[Muterere High School]]
*[[St Columbus High School]]
*Munyuku Secondary School
*Nyamhingura Secondary
*Ngarura Secondary School
*Gatsi High School
* Rupinda Secondary School
*St Peters Secondary School
*Sahumani Secondary School
*Samaringa High School
* Buwu Secondary School
{{Div col end}}

===Tertiary institutions===

==Hospitals and clinics==
*[[Hauna]] District Hospital
*Chisuko Clinic
*Sagambe Clinic
*Katiyo Tea Estate Clinic
*Chavhanga Clinic
*St Peters Mandeya Clinic
*Gatsi Clinic
*Sahumani Clinic
*Chitombo Clinic
*Honde Green Clinic
*Samaringa Clinic
* St peters Jombe Clinic
* Samanga Clinic
* Ngarura Clinic
* Rupinda Clinic
* Hauna Clinic
* Honde mission Clinic
* Samanga Clinic
* Mupotedzi Clinic

==Entertainment and recreation==

===Social clubs===

===Tourist attractions===
* [[Mahwemasimike]] range of mountains which are beautiful to watch for tourists can be seen apart from the [[Hauna]] Growth Point.
* [[Mtarazi Falls]] <ref>[http://www.world-waterfalls.com/database.php?s=N&t=H&orderby=height&sortLimit=300 World Waterfall Database: Worlds Tallest Waterfalls]</ref> - The longest falls in Zimbabwe coming from Nyanga which falls into the Honde River.
* [[Pungwe River]] - fishing and white water rafting
* [[Nyanga National Park]] <ref>[http://www.zimparks.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=23&Itemid=49 Nyanga National Park].</ref>
* [[Honde River]]
* [[Nyawamba Dam]]
* Chipote(Kapunga)Falls
* Honde View - A good view of attractive fauna

===Sports===
Soccer
Rugby

===Leisure===

== Notable places ==
Honde Valley has several villages that include Chavhanga,Sagambe,Rupinda,Rori, Chigweshe, Samushonga, Makwasa, Muparutsa, Zindi, Ngarura, Fenga, Muterere, Bvute, Gatsi, Chijara Village, Mudowaya Village, Zindi Village, Samanga, Bvuma, Honde village, Nyatsuro Village which was taken by [[Katiyo Tea Estates]] during the colonial era, [[Eastern Highland Tea Estates]], chitombo, Samanga, Aberfoyle, Matondora, Chisuko, Sahumani, Green, Makunike, Nyamaende, Rupinda, Costern, Kwambana, Jombe, Mahemasimike, Mandeya, Gwiriri  and Munyuku

==Prominent people from Honde Valley==

title: User talk:Carcassville
content: '''Welcome!''' Hello, {{PAGENAME}}, and [[Wikipedia:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]] to Wikipedia! Thank you for your contributions. I hope you like the place and decide to stay. Here are a few good links for newcomers: *[[Wikipedia:Five pillars|The five pillars of Wikipedia]] *[[Wikipedia:How to edit a page|How to edit a page]] *[[Help:Contents|Help pages]] *[[Wikipedia:Tutorial|Tutorial]] *[[Wikipedia:How to write a great article|How to write a great article]] *[[Wikipedia:Manual of Style|Manual of Style]] I hope you enjoy editing here and being a [[Wikipedia:Wikipedians|Wikipedian]]! Please [[Wikipedia:Sign your posts on talk pages|sign your name]] on talk pages using four tildes (~~~~); this will automatically produce your name and the date. If you need help, check out [[Wikipedia:Where to ask a question]], ask me on my talk page, or place {{helpme}} on your talk page and someone will show up shortly to answer your questions. Again, welcome!  [[User:Goldensun|Goldensun]] 23:33, 23 September 2005 (UTC) == Sonic Youth albums == I don't know why you're changing the infoboxes, but please see [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Albums]]. The accepted infobox is [[Template:Album infobox]]. [[User:Flowerparty|Flower]][[User talk:Flowerparty|party■]] 00:22, 24 September 2005 (UTC) :I was changing the infoboxes to that other format which I have seen used in many other band discographies on Wikipedia. Personally I think they look much better and are easier to read than this standard Wiki infobox that you linked me to. If certain people on Wikipedia are going to attempt to enforce one style of album information box, you all have a lot of work to do in trying to crush the format I was using because lots of people seem to prefer it. Incidentally, by just reverting to the previous edit, you deleted a lot of updates I made to information on the SY album entries other than the infoboxes. Thanks a lot. [[User:Carcassville|Carcassville]] 00:41, 24 September 2005 (UTC) ::I'm sorry if I removed some details. I assumed you were just copying and pasting from old versions, but obviously you put a lot of work in. I've been through and changed things back where I could find them. I should also have pointed you to [[Wikipedia:Wikiproject Albums/Needs infobox conversion]]. Admittedly, having two boxes in use isn't very helpful, but if they're going to be converted it should at least be going in one direction. Please keep up the good work. [[User:Flowerparty|Flower]][[User talk:Flowerparty|party■]] 12:25, 24 September 2005 (UTC)

title: User talk:Ratger
content: == Image:Charvet.jpg == Thanks for uploading '''[[:Image:Charvet.jpg]]'''. I notice the 'image' page specifies that the image is being used under [[Wikipedia:Fair use|fair use]], but its use in Wikipedia articles fails our [[Wikipedia:Fair use criteria|first fair use criterion]] in that it illustrates a subject for which a freely licensed image could reasonably be found or created. If you believe this image is not replaceable, please: # Go to [[:Image:Charvet.jpg|the image description page]] and edit it to add {{[[Template:Replaceable fair use disputed|Replaceable fair use disputed]]}}, '''without deleting the original Replaceable fair use template'''. # On [[Image talk:Charvet.jpg|the image discussion page]], write the reason why this image is not replaceable at all. Alternatively, you can also choose to replace the fair use image by finding a freely licensed image of its subject or by taking a picture of it yourself. If you have uploaded other fair use media, consider checking that you have specified how these images fully satisfy our fair use criteria. You can find a list of 'image' pages you have edited by clicking on [{{fullurl:Special:Contributions|target={{PAGENAMEE}}&namespace=6}} this link]. Note that any fair use images which are replaceable by free-licensed alternatives will be deleted one week after they have been uploaded, as described on [[Wikipedia:Criteria for speedy deletion#Images.2FMedia|criteria for speedy deletion]]. If you have any questions please ask them at the [[Wikipedia:Media copyright questions|Media copyright questions page]]. Thank you. ----[[User:Robth|Robth]][[User Talk:Robth|Talk]] 17:16, 12 November 2006 (UTC)

title: User talk:Airtimes
content:
Please do not add commercial links (or links to your own private websites) to Wikipedia. [[Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not|Wikipedia is not]] a vehicle for [[Wikipedia:Spam|advertising]] or a mere collection of [[Wikipedia:External links|external links]]. You are, however, [[m:When should I link externally|encouraged to add ''content'' instead of links]] to the encyclopedia. See the [[Wikipedia:Welcome, newcomers|welcome page]] to learn more. Thanks. [[User:CambridgeBayWeather|CambridgeBayWeather]] [[User_talk:CambridgeBayWeather|(Talk)]] 17:39, 6 May 2006 (UTC) Please stop. If you continue to use Wikipedia for advertising, you will be [[Wikipedia:Blocking policy|blocked]] from editing. [[User:CambridgeBayWeather|CambridgeBayWeather]] [[User_talk:CambridgeBayWeather|(Talk)]] 17:42, 6 May 2006 (UTC) [[Image:Stop hand.svg|30px|left]] This is your '''last warning'''. The next time you insert a [[Wikipedia:Spam|spam]] link, you ''will'' be blocked from editing Wikipedia. [[User:CambridgeBayWeather|CambridgeBayWeather]] [[User_talk:CambridgeBayWeather|(Talk)]] 17:56, 6 May 2006 (UTC) ==Blocked== [[Image:Octagon-warning.png|left|30px| ]] You have been temporarily blocked from editing Wikipedia for continuing to add [[Wikipedia:Spam|spam]] links. If you wish to make useful contributions, you are welcome to come back after the block expires. [[User:CambridgeBayWeather|CambridgeBayWeather]] [[User_talk:CambridgeBayWeather|(Talk)]] 18:06, 6 May 2006 (UTC) :Unblocked as per emails. [[User:CambridgeBayWeather|CambridgeBayWeather]] [[User_talk:CambridgeBayWeather|(Talk)]] 20:03, 6 May 2006 (UTC) ==Orphaned fair use image (Image:Logocz.gif)== Thanks for uploading '''[[:Image:Logocz.gif]]'''. I notice the 'image' page currently specifies that the image is unlicensed for use on Wikipedia and may only be used on Wikipedia under a [[WP:FU|claim of fair use]]. However, the image is currently [[WP:O|orphaned]], meaning that it is not used in any articles on Wikipedia. If the image was previously in an article, please go to the article and see why it was removed. [[WP:BOLD|You may add it back]] if you think that that will be useful. However, please note that images for which a replacement could be created are not acceptable under fair use (see [[Wikipedia:Fair use#Policy|our fair use policy]]). If you have uploaded other unlicensed media, please check whether they're used in any articles or not. You can find a list of 'image' pages you have edited by clicking on the "[[Special:Contributions/{{PAGENAME}}|my contributions]]" link (it is located at the very top of any Wikipedia page when you are logged in), and then selecting "Image" from the dropdown box. Note that any fair use images not used in any '''articles''' will be deleted after seven days, as described on [[wikipedia:Criteria for speedy deletion#Images.2FMedia|criteria for speedy deletion]]. Thank you. [[User:Gay Cdn|Gay Cdn]] [[User talk:Gay Cdn|(talk)]] [[Special:Contributions/Gay Cdn|(Contr.)]] 01:57, 4 November 2006 (UTC) == Image deletions == Further to your email to me, please have a look at [[Wikipedia:Images and media for deletion]] in regards to nominating an image for deletion. At the top of that page is information about the various speedy categories too. One other speedy way to remove an image is via the {{tl|db-author}} speedy tag. This tag is to be used to delete images (or any pages actually) that '''you, the author''' have created and no-one else has made substantial edits. If you have any other question, please feel free to drop me a note on my talk page.--[[User:Gay Cdn|Gay Cdn]] [[User talk:Gay Cdn|(talk)]] [[Special:Contributions/Gay Cdn|(Contr.)]] 20:14, 4 November 2006 (UTC) ==Orphaned fair use image (Image:Logorw40southwestairways.gif)== Thanks for uploading '''[[:Image:Logorw40southwestairways.gif]]'''. [[User:BigDT|BigDT]] 18:31, 26 December 2006 (UTC) ==Unspecified source for [[:Image:Logoairsouth1970.gif]]== [[Image:Nuvola apps important blue.svg|70px|left]] Thanks for uploading '''[[:Image:Logoairsouth1970.gif]]'''. I noticed that the file's description page currently doesn't specify who created the content, so the [[copyright]] status is unclear. If you did not create this file yourself, then you will need to specify the owner of the copyright. If you obtained it from a website, then a link to the website from which it was taken, together with a restatement of that website's terms of use of its content, is usually sufficient information. However, if the copyright holder is different from the website's publisher, then their copyright should also be acknowledged. As well as adding the source, please add a proper copyright licensing tag if the file doesn't have one already. If you created/took the picture, audio, or video then the {{Tl|GFDL-self}} tag can be used to release it under the [[GFDL]]. If you believe the media meets the criteria at [[Wikipedia:Fair use]], use a tag such as {{tlp|non-free fair use in|article name}} or one of the other tags listed at [[Wikipedia:Image copyright tags#Fair use]]. See [[Wikipedia:Image copyright tags]] for the full list of copyright tags that you can use. If you have uploaded other files, consider checking that you have specified their source and tagged them, too. You can find a list of files you have uploaded by following [{{fullurl:Special:Log|type=upload&user=Airtimes}} this link]. '''Unsourced and untagged images may be deleted one week after they have been tagged''', as described on [[wikipedia:Criteria for speedy deletion#Images.2FMedia|criteria for speedy deletion]]. title: User talk:Bttav11
content: [[Image:Stop hand.svg|left|30px]] Welcome to Wikipedia. We invite everyone to contribute constructively to our encyclopedia. Take a look at the [[Wikipedia:Introduction|welcome page]] if you would like to learn more about contributing. However, unconstructive edits{{#if:{{{1|}}}|, such as those you made to [[:{{{1}}}]],}} are considered [[Wikipedia:Vandalism|vandalism]] and immediately reverted. If you continue in this manner you may be '''[[Wikipedia:blocking policy|blocked]] from editing without further warning'''. Please stop, and consider improving rather than damaging the work of others. Thank you. <!-- Template:Blatantvandal (serious warning) --> [[User:Nunquam Dormio|Nunquam Dormio]] 23:09, 15 February 2007 (UTC)

title: Wikipedia:WikiProject Hawaii/Outreach
content:
The '''outreach department''' of [[WP:HAWAII|WikiProject Hawaii]] is a workgroup for recruiting and retaining active members.  

== Newsletter ==

{{/Newsletter}}

===Archives===
*[[Wikipedia:WikiProject Hawaii/Outreach/Newsletter/April 2008|April 2008]]
*[[Wikipedia:WikiProject Hawaii/Outreach/Newsletter/May 2008|May 2008]]
*[[Wikipedia:WikiProject Hawaii/Outreach/Newsletter/June 2008|June 2008]]
*[[Wikipedia:WikiProject Hawaii/Outreach/Newsletter/July 2008|July 2008]]
*[[Wikipedia:WikiProject Hawaii/Outreach/Newsletter/August 2008|August 2008]]
*[[Wikipedia:WikiProject Hawaii/Outreach/Newsletter/September 2008|September 2008]]
*[[Wikipedia:WikiProject Hawaii/Outreach/Newsletter/October 2008|October 2008]]
*[[Wikipedia:WikiProject Hawaii/Outreach/Newsletter/November 2008|November 2008]]

=== Template ===
<nowiki>{{Wikipedia:WikiProject Hawaii/Outreach/Newsletter/MONTH YEAR}}</nowiki>

==== Monthly ====
<nowiki>{{Wikipedia:WikiProject Hawaii/Outreach/Newsletter/{{CURRENTMONTHNAME}} {{CURRENTYEAR}}}}</nowiki>

== Inviting new members ==
If an editor appears interested in Hawaii-related articles, you can invite them by adding '''<nowiki>{{subst:Hawaii invite}}</nowiki>''' to their talk page. The template, {{tl|Hawaii invite}}, generates the following message:

{{Hawaii invite}}

== Welcoming new members ==
Please welcome all new members by adding '''<nowiki>{{subst:Hawaii welcome}}</nowiki>''' to their talk page. The template, {{tl|Hawaii welcome}}, generates the following message:

{{Hawaii welcome}}

== Awards==
{{Wikipedia:WikiProject Hawaii/Outreach/Awards}}
{{clear}}
[[Category:WikiProject Hawaii newsletters|Outreach]]
[[Category:WikiProject Hawaii|Outreach]]

title: User talk:67.84.177.104
content:
== May 2013 ==
[[Image:Information.svg|left|25px|alt=|link=]] Hello, and welcome to Wikipedia. This is a message letting you know that one of your recent edits to [[:May 12]] has been undone by an automated computer program called [[User:ClueBot NG|ClueBot NG]].

title: Victor I, Duke of Ratibor
content:
{{Infobox royalty|prince | name =Victor I | title =Duke of Ratibor, Prince of Corvey, Prince of Hohenlohe-Schillingsfürst | image =Victor Herzog von Ratibor.jpg | image_size = 190px | caption = Prince Victor ca. 1885 | spouse =Princess Amélie of Fürstenberg | issue =Princess Amelia
[[Victor II, Duke of Ratibor]]
Prince Franz
Princess Elisabeth
Prince Egon
Princess Marie
Prince Maximilian
Prince Ernst
Prince Karl Egon
Princess Margaret | full name ={{lang-de|Viktor Moritz Carl}} | house =[[Hohenlohe|House of Hohenlohe-Schillingsfürst]] | father =Franz Joseph, Prince of Hohenlohe-Schillingsfürst | mother =Princess Constanze of Hohenlohe-Langenburg | birth_date ={{birth date|1818|2|10|df=y}} | birth_place =[[Langenburg]], [[Kingdom of Württemberg]] | death_date ={{death date and age|1893|1|30|1818|2|10|df=y}} | death_place =Schloss Rauden, [[Kingdom of Prussia]] |}} [[File:Ratibor-Corvey-Hohenlohe-Wappen.png|thumb|Arms of the Duke of Ratibor and Prince of Corvey]] '''Victor I, Duke of Ratibor, Prince of Corvey, Prince of Hohenlohe-Schillingsfürst ''' ({{lang-de|Viktor Moritz Carl 1.Herzog von Ratibor, 1.Fürst von Corvey, Prinz zu Hohenlohe-Schillingsfürst}}; 10 February 1818{{spaced ndash}}30 January 1893) was a member of [[Hohenlohe|House of Hohenlohe-Schillingsfürst]] and later [[Duke]] of the [[Duchies of Silesia|Silesian duchy]] of [[Duchy of Racibórz|Ratibor]] ({{lang-cs|Ratiboř}}, {{lang-pl|Racibórz}}). ==Early life and family== Victor was born at [[Langenburg]], [[Kingdom of Württemberg]], eldest son of Franz Joseph, Prince of Hohenlohe-Schillingsfürst (1787–1841), (son of Karl Albrecht II, Prince of Hohenlohe-Schillingsfürs and Baroness Judith Reviczky of Revisnye) and his wife, Princess Constanze of Hohenlohe-Langenburg (1792–1847), (daughter of Karl Ludwig, Prince of Hohenlohe-Langenburg and Countess Amalie of Solms-Baruth). After initial private lessons, he attended the Royal Grammar School in [[Erfurt]]. He then studied law and modern languages in [[Göttingen]], [[Bonn]], [[Heidelberg]] and [[Lausanne]]. He also traveled to [[Switzerland]], [[Italy]], [[France]] and [[England]]. He subsequently managed the property of his uncle, the Landgrave of [[Hesse-Rotenburg]], [[Victor Amadeus, Landgrave of Hesse-Rotenburg|Victor Amadeus]]. These included the former monastery of Corvey in [[Westphalia]], Ratibor in [[Upper Silesia]]. This area was 34,000 hectares in size and consisted mainly of forest areas. Victor was created [[Duchy of Racibórz|Duke of Ratibor]] and Prince of [[Corvey Abbey|Corvey]] on 15 October 1840 by [[Frederick William IV of Prussia|King Frederick William IV of Prussia]]. His younger brother [[Chlodwig, Prince of Hohenlohe-Schillingsfürst|Chlodwig]] was [[Chancellor of Germany]] and [[Minister President of Prussia]] from 1894 to 1900. ==Military career== During his military service, made at an early age in the cavalry. In the 1850s he commanded in repeated exercises the 2nd -[[Landwehr|Landwehr Regiment]]. During the [[Austro-Prussian War]] and the [[Franco-Prussian War]], he organized as Chairman of the Silesian Association Knights Voluntary Health Care. Since 1872, he led the honorary title of General of Cavalry [[à la suite]]. ==Political career== In 1847 Ratibor was a member of the Prussian United Diet. Between 1856 and 1893 he was a member of provincial parliament for [[Silesia Province]]. At first he was Marshal of the Assembly. After the introduction of the new provincial order, he was repeatedly chairman. He was also from 1849 to 1852 on the second chamber of the [[Preußischer Landtag|Prussian State Parliament]]. In 1850 Ratibor was a member of the Erfurt Union Parliament. From 1867 to 1870 he was a member of the [[Reichstag (North German Confederation)|North German Reichstag]], and from 1872 to 1890 of the [[Reichstag (German Empire)|German Reichstag]]. He was also member from 1854 to 1893 of the [[Prussian House of Lords]]. In the latter, he was co-founder of the New Group in 1870/72, from 1877 to 1893 President of the House. Ratibor was one of the liberal-conservative Aristocracy, political reformants, he was a supporter of [[Otto von Bismarck]]. He was also one of the founders of the [[Free Conservative Party]]. ==Marriage== Wilhelm married 19 April 1845 at [[Donaueschingen]] to Princess Amélie of Fürstenberg (1821–1899), daughter of Karl Egon II, Prince of Fürstenberg, and his wife, Princess Amalie of Baden. They had ten children: *Princess Amelia of Hohenlohe-Schillingsfürst (3 October 1846 – 25 August 1847) *[[Victor II, Duke of Ratibor]] (6 September 1847 – 9 August 1923), married in 1867 to Countess Maria Breunner-Enkevoirth, had issue. *Prince Franz of Hohenlohe-Schillingsfürst (6 April 1849 – 27 May 1925) *Princess Elisabeth of Hohenlohe-Schillingsfürst (27 February 1851 – 5 October 1928) *Prince Egon of Hohenlohe-Schillingsfürst (4 January 1853 – 10 February 1896), married in 1885 to Princess Leopoldine of Lobkowicz, had issue. *Princess Marie of Hohenlohe-Schillingsfürst (27 June 1854 – 29 May 1928) *Prince Maximilian of Hohenlohe-Schillingsfürst (9 February 1856 – 12 January 1924), married in 1882 to Countess Franziska Grimaud d'Orsay, had issue. *Prince Ernst of Hohenlohe-Schillingsfürst (10 Nov 1857 – 25 February 1891) *Prince Karl Egon of Hohenlohe-Schillingsfürst (7 July 1860 – 4 June 1940) *Princess Margaret of Hohenlohe-Schillingsfürst (3 June 1863 – 4 June 1940) ==Titles and styles== *'''10 February 1818 – 15 October 1840''': ''His Serene Highness'' Prince Victor of Hohenlohe-Schillingsfürst *'''15 October 1840 – 30 January 1893''': ''His Serene Highness'' The Duke of Ratibor, Prince of Corvey ==Ancestry== {{ahnentafel top|width=100%}} {{ahnentafel-compact5 |style=font-size: 90%; line-height: 110%; |border=1 |boxstyle=padding-top: 0; padding-bottom: 0; |boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; |boxstyle_4=background-color: #bfc; |boxstyle_5=background-color: #9fe; |1= 1. '''Victor I, Duke of Ratibor''' |2= 2. [[Franz Joseph, Prince of Hohenlohe-Schillingsfürst]] |3= 3. Princess Constanze of Hohenlohe-Langenburg |4= 4. [[Karl Albrecht II, Prince of Hohenlohe-Waldenburg-Schillingsfürst]] |5= 5. Baroness Judith Reviczky of Revisnye |6= 6. [[Karl Ludwig, Prince of Hohenlohe-Langenburg]] |7= 7. Baron János Kázmér Reviczky of Revisnye |11= 11. Baroness Róza Perényi of Perény |12= 12. [[Christian Albrecht, Prince of Hohenlohe-Langenburg]] |13= 13. [[Caroline of Stolberg-Gedern (1732–1796)|Countess Caroline of Stolberg-Gedern]] |14= 14. [[Johann Christian II, Count of Solms-Baruth]] |15= 15. Countess Friederike Reuss of Köstritz |16= 16.
